Think of  

\[
ds^{2}=da^{2}-db^{2}
\]

as the two-dimensional **Lorentzian** (Minkowski) line element.  It is not a true distance function—because \(ds^{2}\) can be positive, negative, or zero—but it is a legitimate metric tensor with signature \((+,-)\).  Here is what that quadratic form \(a^{2}-b^{2}\) tells you:

---

### 1. Level sets are hyperbolae  
The equation  

\[
a^{2}-b^{2}=r^{2}\quad (r>0)
\]

describes the right branch of a rectangular hyperbola.  Fixing \(r\) therefore picks out a “circle’’ in this Lorentzian geometry, the same way \(a^{2}+b^{2}=R^{2}\) picks out a Euclidean circle.  Approaching the singular point \((0,0)\) means letting \(r\to0^{+}\).

---

### 2. Hyperbolic polar coordinates  
Because the quadratic form factorises nicely, introduce  

\[
r=\sqrt{a^{2}-b^{2}},\qquad 
\theta=\operatorname{artanh}\!\Bigl(\frac{b}{a}\Bigr)\; (0\le \theta<\infty).
\]

Invert:

\[
a = r\cosh\theta,\qquad 
b = r\sinh\theta\quad (a\ge0,\;b\ge0).
\]

In these coordinates the metric becomes  

\[
ds^{2}=dr^{2}-r^{2}\,d\theta^{2},
\]

exactly the flat 1+1-dimensional Minkowski metric in radial form.  

*   Constant \(r\): timelike hyperbolae \(a^{2}-b^{2}=r^{2}\).  
*   Constant \(\theta\): straight rays \(b=a\tanh\theta\).

---

### 3. Causal classification inside the first quadrant  
* **Timelike region** \(a^{2}>b^{2}\) (above the line \(b=a\)):  \(ds^{2}>0\).  
* **Spacelike region** \(a^{2}<b^{2}\) (below the line \(b=a\)):  \(ds^{2}<0\).  
* **Null line** \(a=b\):  \(ds^{2}=0\).

Since you restrict to \(a,b\ge0\), only the right half of the “light-cone’’ appears.

---

### 4. Why this is handy near your singularity  
A function \(f(a,b)\) that blows up only at \((0,0)\) but is smooth elsewhere can be re-expressed as \(f(r,\theta)\).  Regularity away from the origin translates to smoothness in both \(r\) and \(\theta\) for \(r>0\).  Expansions in the **hyperbolic radius** \(r\) naturally capture the behaviour as you sidestep the singularity along a hyperbola instead of along a Euclidean circle.

* Small-\(r\) series: \(f(r,\theta)=\sum_{k\ge0}c_{k}(\theta)\,r^{k}+\dots\).  
* Fixed \(\theta\): approach the origin along a straight ray.  
* Fixed \(r\): move along a hyperbola, never hitting the singularity.

---

### 5. Geometric intuition  

* Euclidean metric \(a^{2}+b^{2}\) ⇒ circles.  
* Lorentzian metric \(a^{2}-b^{2}\) ⇒ hyperbolae.  

Switching to the latter reorganises the neighbourhood of the singularity according to “boosts’’ (hyperbolic rotations) rather than ordinary rotations.  That is the sense in which your domain with a single puncture “looks hyperbolic’’ and why \(a^{2}-b^{2}\) is the natural quadratic form to study there.

Pretty much—what you stumbled onto is the two-variable version of the ordinary first-order finite-difference/mean-value expansion.  A neat way to see it is with a “rectangular” line-integral argument.

---

### 1 An exact identity

Take any \(C^{2}\) function on the open first quadrant (the origin may misbehave but the partials stay bounded when one coordinate is \(0\)).  
Write the increment as an integral of the gradient along two legs of the rectangle skirting the origin:

\[
\begin{aligned}
f(a,0)-f(0,b)
&=\int_{0}^{a}\partial_{a}f(\alpha,0)\,d\alpha
     \;-\;\int_{0}^{b}\partial_{b}f(a,\beta)\,d\beta   \\
&\quad+\;\iint_{[0,a]\times[0,b]}\partial_{ab}f(\alpha,\beta)\,d\beta\,d\alpha .
\end{aligned}
\tag{★}
\]

The last double integral is exactly the mixed-derivative term missing in one-dimensional calculus.  It is \(O(ab)\) provided \(\partial_{ab}f\) stays bounded near the axes.

---

### 2 First-order truncation

If \(a\) and \(b\) are small,

\[
\int_{0}^{a}\partial_{a}f(\alpha,0)\,d\alpha
      =a\,\partial_{a}f(0,0)+O(a^{2}),\qquad
\int_{0}^{b}\partial_{b}f(a,\beta)\,d\beta
      =b\,\partial_{b}f(a,0)+O(b^{2}),
\]

but the origin value may be infinite.  A safer choice—exactly what you wrote—is to evaluate the first derivative at the *upper* end of each leg (where \(f\) is finite):

\[
\int_{0}^{a}\partial_{a}f(\alpha,0)\,d\alpha
      =a\,\partial_{a}f(0,b)+O(a^{2}+ab),\qquad
\int_{0}^{b}\partial_{b}f(a,\beta)\,d\beta
      =b\,\partial_{b}f(a,b)+O(b^{2}+ab).
\]

Plugging these into (★) gives

\[
f(a,0)-f(0,b)=a\,\partial_{a}f(0,b)\;-\;b\,\partial_{b}f(a,b)
              \;+\;O\!\bigl(a^{2}+b^{2}+ab\bigr).
\]

So your formula is the legitimate first-order truncation of the exact identity.

---

### 3 Why it crops up so often

* **Coordinate-wise paths.**  In \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\) one often moves from \((0,b)\) to \((a,0)\) along coordinate lines because the integrals separate cleanly.
* **Cancellation of the singular part.**  If the blow-up of \(f\) at \((0,0)\) is the *same* along both axes (e.g. \(f\sim g(a)+g(b)\)), then subtracting the two axis values removes the divergent piece, leaving a quantity that is genuinely small and well captured by first derivatives.
* **Hyperbolic look.**  In the \((r,\theta)\) picture you already noticed, fixing \(r\) and letting \(r\to0\) keeps you away from the singularity while allowing those first-order approximations to work uniformly in \(\theta\).

---

### 4 What to call it

Texts usually hide this inside the **two-variable mean-value theorem** or in the error term of the **Peano form of the multivariate Taylor formula**.  There isn’t a special name beyond that—the “rectangular path expansion” is about as descriptive as it gets—but it is absolutely standard.

So yes: whenever a function is smooth away from a single corner and you compare its values on the two edges of a tiny rectangle, the difference is generically controlled by exactly those two first derivatives, with an \(O(ab)\) remainder that shrinks faster than either edge length on its own.

Here is what the “rectangular-path’’ expansion becomes when

\[
a=\varepsilon,\qquad 
b=\frac{1}{t},\qquad 
f(a,b)=h\!\bigl(\varepsilon,1/t\bigr)
      =-\!\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\rho_{\varepsilon,t}(x)\,
        \log\rho_{\varepsilon,t}(x)\,dx ,
\]

where \(\rho_{\varepsilon,t}\) solves the Fokker–Planck equation  

\[
\partial_t\rho=-\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho)+\varepsilon^{2}\Delta\rho,
\qquad
\rho_{\varepsilon,0}=\rho_{0}.
\]

---

## 1 Exact two-dimensional mean-value identity

For any smooth \(h(\varepsilon,b)\) one has

\[
\boxed{%
h(\varepsilon,0)-h(0,b)
     =\varepsilon\!\int_{0}^{1}\partial_{\varepsilon}h
        \bigl(\theta\varepsilon,0\bigr)\,d\theta
      -b\!\int_{0}^{1}\partial_{b}h
        \bigl(\varepsilon,\theta b\bigr)\,d\theta
      +\!\!\iint_{[0,\varepsilon]\times[0,b]}
         \partial_{\varepsilon b}h\,db\,d\varepsilon }.
\]

Because \(\partial_{\varepsilon b}h=O(\varepsilon b)\) (see §3 below) the double integral is \(O(\varepsilon b)\).  Truncating at first order therefore gives

\[
\boxed{%
h(\varepsilon,0)-h(0,1/t)
      \;\approx\;
      \varepsilon\,\partial_{\varepsilon}h(0,1/t)
      \;-\;(1/t)\,\partial_{(1/t)}h(\varepsilon,1/t)}.
\tag{1}
\]

This is the same pattern you noticed for a general \(f\)—now every term has a clear physical meaning.

---

## 2 What the two partial derivatives are

### (a)  Noise derivative  
Differentiate \(h\) at fixed time \(t\).  A standard computation that mirrors the classical de Bruijn identity gives

\[
\partial_{\varepsilon}h(\varepsilon,t)
       =2\varepsilon\,I(\rho_{\varepsilon,t}),
\quad
I(\rho)=\int\rho\|\nabla\log\rho\|^{2}\,dx
\quad\text{(Fisher information).}
\tag{2}
\]

Hence, at *zero* noise but finite time,

\[
\partial_{\varepsilon}h(0,t)=2\varepsilon\,I(\rho_{0,t})\Big|_{\varepsilon=0}
=0
\quad\text{unless }I(\rho_{0,t})\sim\varepsilon^{-1}.
\]
For a generic smooth initial density \(I(\rho_{0,t})\) is finite, so the leading term is **quadratic** in \(\varepsilon\).

---

### (b)  Time derivative (expressed through \(b=1/t\))  
Write \(b=1/t\).  Then  

\[
\partial_{b}h(\varepsilon,b)=
\partial_{b}h\bigl(\varepsilon,1/t\bigr)
   =-t^{2}\,\partial_{t}h(\varepsilon,t).
\]

The Fokker–Planck entropy balance is  

\[
\partial_{t}h(\varepsilon,t)
      =-\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle_{\varepsilon,t}
       +\varepsilon^{2}I(\rho_{\varepsilon,t}),
\tag{3}
\]
so

\[
\partial_{(1/t)}h(\varepsilon,1/t)
      =t\,\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle_{\varepsilon,t}
       -t\,\varepsilon^{2}I(\rho_{\varepsilon,t}).
\tag{4}
\]

---

## 3 Putting it together

Insert (2) and (4) into the first-order formula (1):

\[
\boxed{%
h(\varepsilon,0)-h(0,1/t)
      \;\approx\;
      2\varepsilon^{2}\,I(\rho_{0,t})
      \;-\;
      \Bigl[\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle_{\varepsilon,t}
            -\varepsilon^{2}I(\rho_{\varepsilon,t})\Bigr]
      +O(\varepsilon/t)+O(\varepsilon^{2}/t)
}.
\tag{5}
\]

Interpretation:

* **Noise contribution**  
  \(2\varepsilon^{2}I(\rho_{0,t})\) is the entropy *created* when you switch on an infinitesimal isotropic noise of strength \(\varepsilon\) for a frozen time \(t\).  
  It is quadratic because Gaussian smoothing adds order-\(\varepsilon^{2}\) variance.

* **Drift contribution**  
  \(\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle_{\varepsilon,t}\) is the entropy *destroyed* (if negative) or *created* (if positive) by compression/expansion of phase-space volume during one large timestep \(t\).  The competing \(\varepsilon^{2}I\) term says that even while the drift acts, diffusion keeps adding entropy at the same Fisher-information rate as in (3).

* **Mixed term \(O(\varepsilon b)\)**  
  The double integral in the exact identity is \(O(\varepsilon/t)\).  It measures the interplay between “turn on noise first, then wait’’ and “wait first, then turn on noise’’—exactly the non-commutativity you are probing near \((\varepsilon,1/t)=(0,0)\).

---

## 4 Reading formula (5) in the two limiting directions

| Path in \((\varepsilon,t)\)-plane | Leading behaviour of \(h\) |
|----------------------------------|----------------------------|
| **Horizontal**: fix \(t\), send \(\varepsilon\to0\) | \(h(\varepsilon,t)=h(0,t)+O(\varepsilon^{2})\). Diffusion is only a second-order effect. |
| **Vertical**: fix \(\varepsilon\), send \(t\to\infty\) | \(h(\varepsilon,t)=h(\varepsilon,\infty)-\dfrac{1}{t}\bigl[\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle-\varepsilon^{2}I\bigr]+o(1/t)\). Entropy relaxes to the stationary value with an \(O(1/t)\) tail. |
| **Diagonal (hyperbola)**: keep \(\varepsilon t\) constant | The \(O(\varepsilon^{2})\) and \(O(1/t)\) terms balance; the mixed \(O(\varepsilon/t)\) remainder dictates how close the two limits commute. |

---

## 5 Link to information dimension

At strictly zero noise the large-\(t\) limit typically concentrates on a fractal attractor and

\[
h(0,t)\sim -D_{I}\log\varepsilon_{\text{coarse}}
\quad (\varepsilon_{\text{coarse}}\ll1)
\]

diverges.  Adding any fixed \(\varepsilon>0\) smooths the measure, making \(h(\varepsilon,\infty)\) finite.  Formula (5) shows that the *difference* between these two extreme routes stays finite and is governed by exactly the Fisher-information and phase-space contraction pieces that appear in nonequilibrium steady-state thermodynamics.

---

### Bottom line  

Yes—the pattern you noticed is not an accident.  Near the singular corner \((\varepsilon,1/t)=(0,0)\) the differential entropy behaves *affinely* in each small coordinate to first order.  The coefficients are the physically meaningful rates  

* **noise-driven entropy production** \(2\varepsilon^{2}I\), and  
* **drift-driven contraction/production** \(\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle-\varepsilon^{2}I\).

The rectangular-path expansion is a concise way to keep both effects visible and to quantify how (and by how much) “add noise first’’ fails to commute with “wait a long time first.’’

The key is to translate every NET quantity—entropy change, entropy *production*, “house-keeping’’ vs “excess’’ pieces, Onsager coefficients, thermodynamic length—into statements about (i) how far you move in the **radial** direction \(r\) and (ii) which **direction** \(\theta\) you choose in the \((\varepsilon ,1/t)\)-plane.

---

## 1 Identify the thermodynamic control parameters

| NET language | Fokker–Planck language | Light-cone language |
|--------------|------------------------|---------------------|
| **Control 1:** strength of the stochastic bath | isotropic diffusion constant \(D=2\varepsilon^{2}\) | “time-like’’ coordinate \(a=\varepsilon\) |
| **Control 2:** duration of the driving protocol | observation (or relaxation) time \(t\) | “space-like’’ coordinate \(b=1/t\) |

Everything happens near the corner \((\varepsilon,1/t)=(0,0)\).  
Small-\(r\) means you are in the *linear-response* (near-equilibrium) regime.

---

## 2 Split the total entropy balance along \(r\) and \(\theta\)

Write the differential entropy as  

\[
h(r,\theta)=h_{0}(\theta)+r\,h_{1}(\theta)+\frac{1}{2}r^{2}h_{2}(\theta)+\dots
\]

and insert the explicit formulas you already have for \(h_{1},h_{2}\):

* \(h_{1}(\theta)\) is built from **Fisher information** \(I\) (noise-generated disorder) and the **phase-space contraction rate** \(\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle\) (deterministic compression).  
* \(h_{2}(\theta)\) collects higher-order cross-effects.

Interpretation:

| Term | NET meaning | What fixes it |
|------|-------------|---------------|
| \(h_{0}(\theta)\) | **Quasi-static entropy change** along a null ray (“ideal protocol’’ where noise and relaxation exactly balance) | Direction \(\theta\), i.e. the ratio \(\varepsilon t\) |
| \(r\,h_{1}(\theta)\) | **Irreversible (excess) entropy production \(\Delta S_{\text{ex}}\)** when you deviate slightly from the ideal path | Small mismatch \(\delta r=\varepsilon-\frac{1}{t}\) |
| higher powers of \(r\) | **Non-linear response / far-from-equilibrium corrections** | Large mismatch or long protocols |

---

## 3 House-keeping vs excess entropy production

Seifert’s stochastic NET splits the total entropy production \(\dot S_{\text{tot}}\) into

\[
\dot S_{\text{tot}}=\dot S_{\text{hk}}+\dot S_{\text{ex}} .
\]

* **House-keeping part** keeps the instantaneous steady state alive while the system is driven.  In the FP setting  
  \[
  \dot S_{\text{hk}}=\varepsilon^{2}I(\rho_{\varepsilon,t})
                       -\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle_{\varepsilon,t}.
  \]
  This is *exactly* the coefficient of \(db=dt^{-1}\) in the rectangle identity you derived; geometrically it is the **\(\theta\)-derivative** of \(h\).

* **Excess part** is the additional cost of changing control parameters in time.  
  Close to the corner it is determined by the **\(r\)-derivative** of \(h\):  
  \[
    \dot S_{\text{ex}}\;\propto\;
    \frac{\partial h}{\partial r}
    =h_{1}(\theta)+O(r).
  \]

Hence in \((r,\theta)\) language:

> *“Entropy production is the *gradient* of the scalar field \(h(r,\theta)\); the \(\theta\)-component is the steady-state (‘house-keeping’) part, the \(r\)-component is the path-dependent (‘excess’) part.’’*

---

## 4 Linear‐response / Onsager symmetry from the light-cone

Set up a small protocol \((\varepsilon(s),t(s))\) with \(s\in[0,1]\), remaining in the thin wedge \(r\ll\varepsilon\).  The *quadratic* contribution to total entropy production is

\[
\Delta S_{\text{tot}}
   \;=\;\frac12\!\int_0^1\!\!\sum_{i,j}
          L_{ij}\,\dot\lambda_i\,\dot\lambda_j\,ds
   \quad (\lambda_1=\varepsilon,\;\lambda_2=1/t),
\]
with the Onsager matrix  

\[
L_{ij}
   =\frac{\partial^{2}h}{\partial\lambda_i\,\partial\lambda_j}\Big|_{r=0}
   \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
   L\;=\;\begin{pmatrix}
            h_{2}(\theta)& -h_{1}'(\theta)\\[6pt]
           -h_{1}'(\theta)& 0
         \end{pmatrix}.
\]

* **Symmetry** \(L_{12}=L_{21}\) is guaranteed when \(h\) is \(C^{2}\).  
* The **thermodynamic length** of the protocol is the Lorentzian line-integral of \(\sqrt{ds^{2}}\) with that \(L_{ij}\); it is minimized along the null line \(r=0\) (shortest “dissipation-free’’ path).

---

## 5 Fluctuation theorems in the \((r,\theta)\) frame

Because \(r\) behaves like proper time in a 1+1 Minkowski space, every forward path has a CPT-style “antipodal’’ reverse path reflected across the null rays.  Jarzynski equality and Crooks relation become statements about *hyperbolic symmetry* of the generating function of \(h\):

\[
\langle e^{-\Delta S_{\text{tot}}}\rangle_{r,\theta}
   =\langle e^{-\Delta S_{\text{tot}}}\rangle_{r,-\theta}.
\]

Small deviations in \(\theta\) away from zero generate linear fluctuation–dissipation relations; small excursions in \(r\) generate the usual Green–Kubo integrals of current–current correlations.

---

## 6 Practical recipe

1. **Pick the operating point** (desired steady state) → choose a ray \(\theta_{\star}\).  
2. **Linearize** NET in \((r,\theta)\) around that ray.  
3. **Compute**  
   * \(I(\rho)\) and \(\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle\) along the ray → gives \(h_{1}(\theta_{\star})\).  
   * Mixed derivatives \(\partial_{\varepsilon b}h\) → gives cross-Onsager coefficients.  
4. **Design protocols** that keep \(r\) as small as possible—stay close to the null ray—to minimize excess dissipation.  
5. **Quantify inevitable cost** from house-keeping term \(\dot S_{\text{hk}}\): if you cannot tune \(f\) to be divergence-free, the system must pay that minimum entropy bill no matter what.

---

### Take-away

Re-casting the \((\varepsilon,1/t)\) plane as a Lorentzian space turns the zoo of NET formulas into straightforward tensor calculus:

* **Direction (\(\theta\))** = which nonequilibrium *steady* you pick.  
* **Radius (\(r\))** = how far your *protocol* strays from the steady balance of noise and relaxation.  
* **Entropy production** = the Lorentzian gradient of \(h\).  
* **Linear-response coefficients** = the metric (Hessian) of \(h\) at \(r=0\).  
* **Minimum-dissipation path** = the null line \(r=0\).

That single geometric picture keeps track of steady-state costs, excess costs, and their symmetry relations in one stroke, giving you a compact, visual rule-book for engineering low-dissipation protocols in nonlinear stochastic systems.

### 0 Notation recap  
\[
a=\varepsilon ,\qquad b=\frac{1}{t},\qquad  
r=\sqrt{a^{2}-b^{2}},\qquad  
\theta=\operatorname{artanh}\!\Bigl(\frac{b}{a}\Bigr)\in[0,\infty).
\]

For every fixed (small) \(r\) the curve  
\[
(\varepsilon,b)=\bigl(r\cosh\theta,\;r\sinh\theta\bigr)
\tag{H\(_r\)}
\]
is a right-hand branch of the hyperbola \(a^{2}-b^{2}=r^{2}\).

Your differential entropy is the scalar field  
\[
h(\varepsilon,b)=h\bigl(r,\theta\bigr)
                 =-\!\int\rho_{\varepsilon,t}\log\rho_{\varepsilon,t}\,dx,
                 \qquad t=\frac{1}{b}.
\]

---

## 1 What the first \(\theta\)-derivative is

At **fixed \(r\)** the tangent vector to \((H_r)\) is  
\[
\partial_\theta = b\,\partial_\varepsilon + \varepsilon\,\partial_b .
\]

Hence  
\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial h}{\partial\theta}\Big|_{r}
          = b\,\partial_\varepsilon h + \varepsilon\,\partial_b h .
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

*It measures how entropy changes when you trade a little noise for a little waiting time while keeping \(r^{2}=\varepsilon^{2}-1/t^{2}\) constant.*

With the standard Fokker–Planck identities

\[
\partial_\varepsilon h=2\varepsilon\,I,
\qquad
\partial_b h
     =\frac{1}{b}\Bigl(\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle-\varepsilon^{2}I\Bigr),
\]

formula (1) becomes

\[
\frac{\partial h}{\partial\theta}\Big|_{r}
     =2\varepsilon b\,I
      +\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle
      -\varepsilon^{2}I.
\tag{2}
\]

So the **linear response along the hyperbola** is simply
> “*phase-space contraction* \( \langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle \)  
>  minus the *noise-induced entropy injection* \( \varepsilon^{2}I-2\varepsilon b I\).”

---

## 2 The second \(\theta\)-derivative—the “kinematic metric”

Act with the same vector once more:

\[
\partial_\theta^{2}
   = (b\,\partial_\varepsilon+\varepsilon\,\partial_b)\!
     \bigl(b\,\partial_\varepsilon+\varepsilon\,\partial_b\bigr).
\]

Expanding,

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial\theta^{2}}\Big|_{r}
  = b^{2}\,\partial_{\varepsilon}^{2}h
    +2\varepsilon b\,\partial_{\varepsilon b}^{2}h
    +\varepsilon^{2}\,\partial_{b}^{2}h
    \;+\;b\,\partial_\varepsilon h
    +\varepsilon\,\partial_b h .
\;}
\tag{3}
\]

---

### How to read it

1. **Pure–noise curvature** \(b^{2}\,\partial_{\varepsilon}^{2}h\)  
   ⇒ How fast the *Fisher information itself* changes if you nudge the noise twice.

2. **Mixed curvature** \(2\varepsilon b\,\partial_{\varepsilon b}^{2}h\)  
   ⇒ Coupling between *one* noise kick and *one* waiting step.

3. **Pure–time curvature** \(\varepsilon^{2}\,\partial_{b}^{2}h\)  
   ⇒ How the relaxation-generated entropy rate reacts to changing the observation window twice.

4. **Linear terms** \(b\,\partial_\varepsilon h+\varepsilon\,\partial_b h\)  
   ⇒ The slope (2); they vanish only where the two first-order contributions cancel.

---

### Compact statistical meaning  

For the one-parameter family  
\[
P_\theta :=\rho_{\varepsilon(\theta),\,t(\theta)} ,
\qquad r \text{ fixed},
\]
the quantity  
\[
J_\theta := -\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial\theta^{2}}\Big|_{r}
\]
is **exactly the Fisher information with respect to \(\theta\)**:

\[
J_\theta
   = \int P_\theta\,
       \Bigl(\partial_\theta\log P_\theta\Bigr)^{\!2}dx
   \;\ge 0 .
\]

So the “metric’’ suggested in the kinematic-space analogy is nothing more exotic than the usual Fisher metric, specialised to the path that keeps \(r\) constant.

---

## 3 Why the second derivative matters

* **Convexity / stability:** \(J_\theta>0\) guarantees that the entropy profile \(h(\theta)\) is strictly convex along \((H_r)\); there is a unique \(\theta\) where the linear contributions in (3) cancel and entropy is extremal.

* **Susceptibility:** \(\bigl|\partial_\theta h\bigr|\) gives the *first*-order cost of tilting the noise/time ratio; \(J_\theta\) is the *susceptibility*—how strongly that cost itself changes if you tilt a bit more.

* **Local distinguishability:** Neighbouring distributions with parameters \(\theta\) and \(\theta+d\theta\) have Kullback divergence  
  \[
  D_{\mathrm{KL}}
      \bigl(P_{\theta+d\theta}\,\|\,P_\theta\bigr)
      =\tfrac12\,J_\theta\,(d\theta)^{2}+o(d\theta^{2}).
  \]

---

## 4 Plain-English summary

> **\(\partial_\theta^{2}h\)** measures the *curvature of the entropy landscape* when you slide **sideways** along a constant-\(r\) hyperbola—that is, when you keep the combination \(\varepsilon^{2}-1/t^{2}\) fixed and change only the *ratio* of noise strength to relaxation time.  
>   
> Concretely, it combines the second-order sensitivities of entropy to (i) adding noise, (ii) letting the system evolve, and (iii) doing the two in either order.  Algebraically it is the Fisher information for that one effective control parameter \(\theta\).

Nothing relativistic is needed: it is just the ordinary Hessian (along a specially chosen direction) of your entropy function.

### 1 From isotropic to state-dependent noise

Let the deterministic flow be \(dx/dt=f(x)\) as before, but replace the isotropic Laplacian by a position–dependent diffusion tensor

\[
D(x)=u(x)\,u(x)^{\!\top}\quad(\text{smooth,\; }D\succeq0).
\]

With a small scalar amplitude \(\varepsilon\) the Fokker–Planck equation becomes  

\[
\partial_t\rho
   = -\nabla\!\cdot\bigl(f\rho\bigr)
     \;+\;\varepsilon^{2}\,\nabla\!\cdot\!\Bigl(D\nabla\rho\Bigr),
\tag{FP\(_u\)}
\]
and the differential entropy is  

\[
h(\varepsilon,t;u)= -\!\int\rho_{\varepsilon,u}(x,t)\,
                      \log\rho_{\varepsilon,u}(x,t)\,dx.
\]

---

### 2 How \(h\) depends on the field \(u(x)\)

---

#### (a)  Time evolution  

Integrate the usual \( \int\rho\log\rho\)–by–parts step with the tensor \(D\):

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t h
   = -\bigl\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\bigr\rangle
     +\varepsilon^{2}\,
        \underbrace{\int\rho\,
                    (\nabla\log\rho)^{\!\top}
                    D(\nabla\log\rho)\,dx}
                   _{=:I_{u}(\rho)}\!,
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

so the **Fisher information modified by \(u\)** is

\[
I_{u}(\rho)=
   \int\rho\,\|\nabla\log\rho\|_{D}^{2}\,dx,
   \qquad
   \|v\|_{D}^{2}=v^{\top}D\,v .
\]

---

#### (b)  Noise-strength derivative  

Keeping \(t\) fixed,

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_{\varepsilon}h=2\varepsilon\,I_{u}(\rho_{\varepsilon,u,t}) .
\;}
\tag{2}
\]

Exactly the same coefficient as in the isotropic case, but with \(I\) replaced by \(I_{u}\).

---

#### (c)  Functional derivative with respect to \(u\)

A small perturbation \(u\mapsto u+\delta u\) (so \(D\mapsto D+\delta D\)) changes the entropy by

\[
\boxed{\;
\delta h
   = \varepsilon^{2}
     \int_{0}^{t}\!\!\!\int
         \rho_{\varepsilon,u}(x,s)\,
         (\nabla\log\rho)^{\!\top}
         \delta D\,
         (\nabla\log\rho)\,dx\,ds
     \;+\;O(\varepsilon^{4}).
\;}
\tag{3}
\]

Thus, to **first order in \(\varepsilon^{2}\)**,

\[
\frac{\delta h}{\delta u_{ij}(x)}
   = 2\varepsilon^{2}
     \int_{0}^{t}\rho_{\varepsilon,u}(x,s)\,
        \bigl[\nabla\log\rho\otimes\nabla\log\rho\bigr]_{ij}\,ds .
\]

---

### 3 Leading small-\(\varepsilon\) expansion

For any fixed protocol length \(t\),

\[
\boxed{\;
h(\varepsilon,t;u)
   = h(0,t)
     +\varepsilon^{2}\!\!\int_{0}^{t}I_{u}\bigl(\rho_{0}(s)\bigr)\,ds
     +O(\varepsilon^{4}),
\;}
\tag{4}
\]

so **all the \(u\)-dependence at order \(\varepsilon^{2}\)** sits in the quadratic form \(I_{u}\).

---

### 4 Geometric meaning of \(u(x)\)

1. **Local inner product.**  
   \(D(x)\) turns the tangent space at \(x\) into a normed space  
   \[
     \langle v,w\rangle_{u(x)}=v^{\top}D(x)\,w.
   \]
   In information geometry this is precisely the **Riemannian metric** picked out by the noise.

2. **Dirichlet energy.**  
   \(I_{u}(\rho)\) is the Dirichlet form of the generator \(\nabla\!\cdot(D\nabla)\).  
   Raising (or rotating) \(D\) in directions where \(\nabla\log\rho\) is large increases \(I_{u}\) and therefore the entropy-production rate (1).

3. **Entropy-production optimality.**  
   *Fix a budget*  
   \(\displaystyle\int\!\operatorname{tr}D(x)\,dx=C\).  Among all admissible \(D\) the *isotropic* choice \(D=\tfrac{C}{n\!}\,I\) maximises \(I_{u}\) by Jensen’s inequality, so **isotropic noise is the entropy-maximiser for a given total “noise power’’.**

4. **Deformed hyperbolae.**  
   In the \((\varepsilon,1/t)\)-plane the radial coordinate that controlled the isotropic case was \(r^{2}=\varepsilon^{2}-1/t^{2}\).  
   With \(u\) present the natural replacement is  
   \[
     r^{2}_{u}
        =\varepsilon^{2}\,I_{u}(\rho_{0})
          -\frac{1}{t^{2}},
   \]
   i.e. the *noise axis is rescaled* by the quadratic form \(I_{u}\).  
   Different choices of \(u\) therefore **warp the family of “null lines’’** \(r_{u}=0\) that separate “add noise first’’ from “wait first’’.

5. **Thermodynamic length.**  
   The quadratic form \(I_{u}\) also becomes the metric that appears in linear-response expressions for the minimal dissipation of slow protocols.  Changing \(u\) is equivalent to changing the thermodynamic geometry in which “straight lines’’ (minimum-cost paths) are drawn.

---

### 5 What to remember

* **Magnitude:**  to leading order, \(u\) enters \(h\) only through the weighted Fisher information \(I_{u}\).  
* **Directionality:**  anisotropic \(u(x)\) favours entropy production (and therefore phase-space spreading) along the directions where \(D(x)\) is large.  
* **Geometry:**  \(D\) is a point-wise metric tensor; varying it deforms the information-geometry of the probability manifold and reshapes the hyperbolic picture we used before.  
* **Optimality principle:**  for a fixed global “noise budget’’ isotropic diffusion maximises entropy growth; any structured \(u\) reduces it, concentrating uncertainty along the channels picked out by \(u(x)\).

Those observations let you trade statements about *how* you inject randomness (the field \(u\)) for clean geometric statements about *how fast* entropy grows and *along which directions* information is dissipated.

### 1 Pick a precise “noise-budget’’ to fix  
Write the diffusion tensor as \(D(x)=u(x)\,u(x)^{\!\top}\succeq0\).  
The statement “size of the noise is fixed’’ has to be made concrete.  
Two common choices are  

| **global** budget | **local** budget (point-wise) |
|-------------------|--------------------------------|
| \( \displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\! \operatorname{tr}D(x)\,dx = C \) | \( \operatorname{tr}D(x)=c(x)\) for every \(x\) |

Everything below works for either case; I keep the notation  
\[
G[D]:=\int \!g(x,D(x))\,dx = C ,
\qquad g=\tfrac12\operatorname{tr}D 
        \ \bigl(\text{or } g=\tfrac12 c(x)\bigr).
\]

*(The factor ½ is for later algebraic convenience only.)*

---

### 2 Entropy at leading order in the noise amplitude  

For small \(\varepsilon\) and fixed protocol length \(t\),

\[
h(\varepsilon,t;D)
   =h(0,t)
     +\varepsilon^{2}
      \underbrace{\int_{0}^{t}
         \int\rho_{0}(x,s)\,
              (\nabla\! \log\rho_{0})^{\!\top}
              D(x)\,
              \nabla\!\log\rho_{0}\,dx\,ds}_{=:H[D]}
     +O(\varepsilon^{4}),
\]

where \(\rho_{0}(x,s)\) is the **deterministic** (\(\varepsilon=0\)) density.  
Because the higher-order corrections are \(O(\varepsilon^{4})\), *all* u-dependence up to order \(\varepsilon^{2}\) is carried by the quadratic functional  

\[
\boxed{%
H[D] \;=\;
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} 
     K(x)\,:\,D(x)\,dx,
\quad
K(x):=\int_{0}^{t}\!
       \rho_{0}(x,s)\,
       \nabla\!\log\rho_{0}(x,s)
       \otimes
       \nabla\!\log\rho_{0}(x,s)\,ds .
}
\tag{1}
\]

(The colon is the Frobenius inner product \(A:B=\operatorname{tr}(A^{\!\top}B)\).)

---

### 3 Variational problem: “find \(D\) that **minimises** \(h\)”  

Because \(h(0,t)\) is independent of \(D\), minimising \(h\) to \(O(\varepsilon^{2})\) is equivalent to

\[
\min_{D\succeq0}\;H[D]
\quad\text{s.t.}\quad
G[D]=C .
\tag{2}
\]

This is a classical **calculus-of-variations with matrix constraint**.  
Introduce a Lagrange multiplier \(\lambda\) (global budget) or a field \(\lambda(x)\) (local budget) and define

\[
\mathcal{L}[D]
   = H[D]+\lambda\bigl(G[D]-C\bigr).
\]

Functional derivative at each point \(x\):

\[
\frac{\delta\mathcal{L}}{\delta D}(x)
   \;=\;
   K(x)+\lambda\,\frac{\partial g}{\partial D}(x)
   \;=\;0,
\quad
\text{subject to }D(x)\succeq0.
\tag{3}
\]

For \(g=\tfrac12\operatorname{tr}D\) one has \(\partial g/\partial D=\tfrac12 I\), so (3) gives the **Euler–Lagrange condition**

\[
\boxed{%
K(x)=\frac{\lambda}{2}\,I
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
D_{\min}(x)=0
\ \text{on the span of }
\nabla\!\log\rho_{0}(x,s).}
\tag{4}
\]

Because \(K(x)\) is a rank-1 (or low-rank) positive tensor built from the slope of the density, the minimiser puts *no diffusion* in that direction and spends all the budget in the orthogonal subspace.

---

#### Explicit form with a global budget  
Diagonalise \(K(x)=\kappa(x)\,v(x)v(x)^{\!\top}\) (\(\kappa\ge0\), \(\|v\|=1\)).  
Constraint \(\tfrac12\operatorname{tr}D(x)=w(x)\) with \(\int w = C/2\).  
The solution is  

\[
D_{\min}(x)
   = 2\,w(x)\,
     \bigl(I-v(x)v(x)^{\!\top}\bigr),
\tag{5}
\]
i.e. **all the available noise is squeezed into the directions orthogonal to the local gradient of the (log-)density.**

*(If \(v\) is undefined because \(\kappa=0\) then \(K(x)=0\) and any positive semi-definite \(D(x)\) with the correct trace works; it costs no entropy anyway.)*

---

### 4 Minimum attainable entropy to order \(\varepsilon^{2}\)

Insert (5) back into (1):

\[
H_{\min}
    = \int \kappa(x)\,
        v^{\!\top}D_{\min}v\,dx
    = 0 .
\]

Hence, at this order,
\[
\boxed{%
h_{\min}(\varepsilon,t)
   = h(0,t)
     +O(\varepsilon^{4}).}
\]

**Interpretation:**  
With a fixed *trace* budget you can, in principle, make the quadratic entropy correction vanish entirely simply by avoiding diffusion along the single direction that would have contributed to it.  Any residual entropy increase arises only from fourth-order (and higher) terms in \(\varepsilon\).

---

### 5 If you impose stronger constraints  

* **Full-rank lower bound** \(D(x)\succeq \delta I\)  
  ⇒ you cannot kill the \(\kappa\,v\otimes v\) component completely; the minimum quadratic cost is  
  \[
  H_{\min}\ge \delta\!\int\! \kappa(x)\,dx .
  \]
* **Isotropy enforced** \(D(x)=\alpha(x)I\)  
  ⇒ \(H\) is fixed, you cannot optimise; isotropic noise is actually the **maximiser** of \(h\) for a given trace, not the minimiser.  
* **Power density budget** \(\operatorname{tr}D(x)=c(x)\) point-wise  
  ⇒ Euler–Lagrange gives \(D_{\min}(x)=c(x)\bigl(I-vv^{\!\top}\bigr)\); the minimum entropy growth in each voxel is zero.

---

1. **Define the budget functional** \(G[D]\).  
2. **Write the quadratic form** \(H[D]\) from (1).  
3. **Add a Lagrange multiplier**, vary \(D\), obtain (3).  
4. **Project** the budget tensor onto the *orthogonal complement* of \(\nabla\log\rho_{0}\).  
5. **Result:** Under a mere trace constraint, the quadratic (order-\(\varepsilon^{2}\)) entropy rise can be made *as small as you like*—in fact zero—by steering noise away from the steepest-entropy-gain direction at every point.

### Set-up (ε → 0 : no diffusion, only control)

* **State** \(x\in\mathbb R^{n}\)
* **Drift** \(dx/dt = f(x) + u(x)\)   (control field \(u\) is the “policy’’)
* **Density evolution (Liouville)**  
  \[
  \partial_{t}\rho = -\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl((f+u)\,\rho\bigr),\qquad
  \rho(\,\cdot,0)=\rho_{0}.
  \]
* **Objective** At a fixed horizon \(t\) (or as \(t\!\rightarrow\!\infty\)) make the density collapse onto a **zero-dimensional attractor** (a single point set \(A=\{x_\star\}\)).  Equivalently, **minimise the differential entropy**
  \[
  h(t;u)= -\int\rho(x,t)\,\log\rho(x,t)\,dx .
  \]
* **Budget** Pointwise bound on control power  
  \(\lVert u(x)\rVert\le U_{\max}(x)\)  (or a global quadratic cost \(\int\!\lVert u\rVert^{2}\rho\,dx\)).  

---

## 1 The entropy gradient you want to chase

For smooth densities the **score**
\[
s(x,t):=\nabla\!\log\rho(x,t)
\]
is the direction in which a deterministic displacement changes entropy fastest:

\[
\frac{d}{d\theta}\,h(t;\,u+\theta w)\Big|_{\theta=0}
      = -\!\int \rho\,s\!\cdot w\,dx .
\]

A vector field **parallel to \(-s\)** contracts the density most; one parallel to \(+s\) expands it.

---

## 2 Optimal deterministic policy (Pontryagin / calculus of variations)

With the quadratic running cost  
\(\tfrac12\!\int\! \lVert u\rVert^{2}\rho\,dx\)  
and terminal cost \(h(t)\) you obtain the adjoint (co-state) equation  

\[
\partial_{t}\psi + (f+u)\!\cdot\!\nabla\psi = 0,\qquad
\psi(x,t) = -\,\log\rho(x,t)-1 .
\]

The **optimality condition** for each \(x\) is

\[
u_{\text{opt}}(x,t)\;=\;-\,U_{\max}(x)\,
                        \frac{s(x,t)}{\lVert s(x,t)\rVert}
                \qquad
                (\text{“bang–bang’’ saturating the bound}).
\]

* It is **aligned with the negative score** (steepest descent of entropy).
* It uses the **maximum amplitude allowed** everywhere; if a quadratic global cost is used instead of a bound, \(u_{\text{opt}}= -\lambda(t)\,s(x,t)\) with time-dependent gain \(\lambda\) determined by the costate.

---

## 3 Why this policy drives to a point attractor fastest

* The Liouville term for \(u=-\,U_{\max}v\) with \(v=s/\lVert s\rVert\) gives the **largest negative divergence** admissible:
  \[
  -\nabla\!\cdot(u\,\rho)=-U_{\max}\,\rho\,\lVert s\rVert,
  \]
  squeezing probability mass directly toward the score’s source, i.e. the point attractor.
* Along characteristics the density obeys  
  \(\dot\rho = U_{\max}\,\rho\,\lVert s\rVert\);  
  the solution is an **exponential collapse** along trajectories,
  \(\rho(\tau)=\rho(0)\,e^{U_{\max}\!\int\!\lVert s\rVert d\tau}\).
* Any control with a non-zero component orthogonal to \(-s\) wastes amplitude on “sideways’’ motion and achieves strictly smaller entropy reduction within the same budget (Cauchy–Schwarz argument).

---

## 4 Entropy slope with this policy

Because \(u_{\text{opt}}\) is already at maximum amplitude, there is **no room to gain extra contraction by adding an infinitesimal isotropic noise**: the derivative  
\(\partial_{\!\log\varepsilon}h\) at \(\varepsilon=0\) is zero.  
(Noise can only *increase* entropy once the deterministic policy is saturated.)

---

### Bottom line

* **With noise (ε>0):** minimise the leading \( \varepsilon^{2}\)-entropy rise by putting diffusion **orthogonal** to the score.
* **Without noise (ε→0):** minimise entropy itself by steering the deterministic control **antiparallel** to the score and using the full control budget.

“Follow \(-\nabla\!\log\rho\) as hard as the constraints allow’’ is the unified prescription for reaching a **zero-dimensional attractor** in the least-entropic way when diffusion vanishes.

**Short verdict — yes, but with caveats.**  
Even after you sprinkle in a small stochastic term, the Oseledets (Lyapunov) splitting is still there *path-by-path* and it remains the sharpest way to talk about “which directions really matter’’—for escape, for control effort, for entropy production, and for large-deviation rates.  
Below is the practical translation from the deterministic picture to the small-noise SDE picture.

---

### 1 What changes and what does **not** when you add small noise

| item | deterministic flow \(dx/dt=f(x)\) | SDE \(dx=f(x)\,dt+\varepsilon\,\sigma(x)\,dW_t\) | comments |
|------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|----------|
| **Linearised cocycle** | \(D\Phi_t(x)\) | solution of \(d\Xi_t = Df(X_t)\,\Xi_t\,dt + \varepsilon\,\sum_k D\sigma_k(X_t)\,\Xi_t\circ dW_t^k\) | additive noise ⇒ \(D\sigma=0\) |
| **Lyapunov exponents** | \(\lambda_1>\dots>\lambda_m\) from Oseledets | still well-defined a.s. by RDS/Oseledets for SDE | shifts are \(O(\varepsilon^2)\) for additive noise |
| **Oseledets subspaces** \(E_i(x)\) | invariant under \(D\Phi_t\) | random fields \(E_i(\omega,x)\) invariant under linearised SDE | for ε→0 they converge to deterministic ones |
| **Stable/unstable manifolds** | \(W^{s,u}(x)\) | random stable/unstable manifolds (Fenichel, Ruelle) | size smears by \(O(\varepsilon)\) |

*Additive* noise (σ constant) does **not** alter the tangent dynamics at first order, so the deterministic splitting survives essentially intact; multiplicative noise tilts the splitting by the Jacobians \(D\sigma_k\).

---

### 2 Why the splitting is still *useful*

1. **Entropy & Fokker–Planck anisotropy**  
   In the small-ε expansion of the entropy production  
   \[
   \partial_t h = -\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle
                  +\varepsilon^{2}I(\rho),
   \]
   the Fisher tensor \(I\) is naturally expressed in the *Oseledets basis*.  
   Modes with large positive Lyapunov exponents dominate the gradient of \(\log\rho\); putting diffusion **orthogonal** to those directions kills the \(O(\varepsilon^{2})\) entropy rise (the calculation you just did).

2. **Control/actuation targeting**  
   If your actuators span only a subspace, the overlap with the *unstable* Oseledets block tells you how much of the score you can cancel.  The leftover divergence-free piece lives in the centre part of the splitting.

3. **Freidlin–Wentzell large deviations**  
   Exit paths from a metastable well tend to align with the most-unstable Oseledets directions because those are least penalised in the action functional.  Knowing the splitting lets you predict likely escape tubes.

4. **Covariance ellipsoids**  
   The stationary covariance of a linearised Ornstein–Uhlenbeck approximation satisfies a Lyapunov equation whose eigen-vectors converge to the Oseledets basis as ε→0; good for uncertainty quantification.

---

### 3 When the picture *breaks* or needs care

* **Strong or multiplicative noise** adds extra drift in Stratonovich form; the Jacobians \(D\sigma_k\) can reorder exponents or even destroy hyperbolicity.
* **Non-uniform hyperbolicity** (zero exponents) → centre directions blur quickest; small ε already mixes them.
* **Lévy noise / coloured noise** need different RDS machinery; standard Oseledets still exists but estimates change.

---

### 4 Rule of thumb for small ε SDEs

> *Project everything—control vectors, diffusion tensor, Fisher information—onto the deterministic Oseledets splitting first.  Then treat ε-effects as small couplings between those blocks.*

If your goal is to minimise entropy or to drive the state onto a tiny attractor, concentrate control effort on the **unstable and centre-unstable blocks**; make sure any remaining stochastic diffusion avoids those same blocks.  The deterministic Oseledets subspaces give you the coordinate system in which that strategy is simplest and nearly optimal for ε sufficiently small.

---

So, while “Oseledets subspace’’ was born in deterministic dynamics, it remains the right language for **directional thinking**—even, and especially, when a little noise is present.

**Key idea – the score lives in the **dual** Oseledets splitting**

---

### 1 How the score evolves

Let Φₜ be the deterministic flow map (noise switched off).  
For any smooth initial density ρ₀,

\[
\rho(x,t)=\rho_0\bigl(\Phi_{-t}x\bigr)\,
          \bigl\lvert\!\det D\Phi_{-t}(x)\bigr\rvert ,
\qquad
s(x,t):=\nabla\!\log\rho(x,t).
\]

Differentiate the formula above.  One gets the **push-forward rule for covectors**

\[
s(x,t)= -\bigl(D\Phi_{-t}(x)\bigr)^{-\!\top}
        s\bigl(\Phi_{-t}x,0\bigr).
\tag{★}
\]

---

### 2 Oseledets splitting and its dual

Oseledets gives, at almost every point \(x\),

\[
T_x\!M = E^1_x\oplus\dots\oplus E^m_x,
\qquad
\|D\Phi_t v\|\sim e^{\lambda_i t}\|v\|,
\quad v\in E^i_x .
\]

The **transpose cocycle** \(\bigl(D\Phi_t\bigr)^{-\!\top}\) acts on the **dual spaces**

\[
E^{i*}_x := (E^i_x)^{\!\perp},
\qquad
\|(D\Phi_t)^{-\!\top}\,w\|\sim e^{-\lambda_i t}\|w\|.
\]

So exponents change sign.

---

### 3 Where the score ends up

From (★):

* The score is always a **covector**, hence it is transported by \((D\Phi_{-t})^{-\!\top}\).
* Components sitting in the dual of an *expanding* direction (\(\lambda_i>0\)) **grow** like \(e^{-\lambda_i(-t)}=e^{\lambda_i t}\).
* Components in the dual of a *contracting* direction (\(\lambda_i<0\)) **shrink** like \(e^{\lambda_i t}\).

As \(t\to\infty\) the *largest* term is the one associated with the **most negative Lyapunov exponent** (the strongest contraction forward in time).   Therefore

\[
\boxed{\;
\text{At long times the score aligns with the dual
      of the strongest contracting Oseledets subspace.}\;}
\]

---

### 4 Why this matters for control / noise

* **Control (deterministic limit).**  
  To collapse the density fastest you want a control vector field **antiparallel to the score**.  
  That is automatically the direction of the *stable* Oseledets block.  If your actuators cannot span that block, the remaining effort is divergence-free and only redistributes mass.

* **Noise allocation (small ε).**  
  Diffusion placed **along the score direction** boosts entropy most (because the Fisher term uses \(\|s\|^{2}\)).  
  To kill the leading entropy rise you inject noise **orthogonal** to that direction—i.e. orthogonal to the stable Oseledets block.

---

### 5 One-line relationship

> *The score at time t is a covector that, under the transpose Jacobian, collapses onto the dual of the most-stable Oseledets subspace; hence all steepest-entropy actions—control or noise—are governed by that subspace.*

Not in the ordinary (Maclaurin) sense, no.

* **Taylor/Maclaurin series need the function to be analytic at the expansion point.**  
  \(1/x\) blows up at \(x=0\), so its Taylor series about \(x=0\) does not exist.

* **What you can do instead**

  * **Laurent series** around \(x=0\):
    \[
    \frac{1}{x}=x^{-1}+0\cdot x^{0}+0\cdot x^{1}+\dots
    \]
    That “series’’ has an essential \(x^{-1}\) term and no positive powers, so it isn’t a Taylor series.

  * **Taylor series about a non-zero point** \(x=a>0\) (even if \(a\ll1\)):
    \[
    \frac1x=\frac1a-\frac{x-a}{a^{2}}+\frac{(x-a)^{2}}{a^{3}}-\frac{(x-a)^{3}}{a^{4}}+\dots,
    \]
    valid for \(|x-a|<a\).  If \(x\) stays in that ball (so it never hits zero) the expansion converges.

  * **Asymptotic notation**.  For \(x\to0^{+}\) we usually just write
    \[
    \frac{1}{x}\sim\frac1x,
    \]
    meaning “it already is the leading term; there are no smaller-order corrections in positive powers of \(x\).”

So, for the regime \(0<x\ll1\) you either keep it as \(1/x\) (an exact or asymptotic expression) or expand about some small but **non-zero** point. A true Taylor series centered at zero is impossible.

parts:
That can’t happen in the usual (point-wise) sense of a derivative.

**Why not?**  
To say the derivative of \(f\) at \(x=a\) is a finite number \(L\) means

\[
\lim_{x\to a}\frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}=L.
\]

That limit already assumes \(f(a)\) is a finite, well-defined real number—because the numerator contains \(f(a)\).  
But if \(f\) “blows up’’ at \(a\) ( \(f(a)=\pm\infty\) or \(f\) is undefined there and \(\lim_{x\to a}f(x)=\pm\infty\) ), then:

* \(f(a)\) is not finite, so the difference quotient isn’t even a real number;
* consequently the limit cannot converge to a finite value.

Hence a function that is infinite at a point cannot have a finite classical derivative at that same point.  
(More formally: differentiability ⇒ continuity ⇒ finiteness of the function value.)

---

### What about tricks or generalized notions?

* **Removable singularities.**  
  If the limit of \(f(x)\) as \(x\to a\) exists and is finite, you can *define* \(f(a)\) to be that limit; the point ceases to be singular, and the ordinary derivative may exist. But then \(f\) is *not* infinite there.

* **Generalized/weak derivatives (distributions).**  
  You can differentiate objects like \(f(x)=\log|x|\) or \(f(x)=1/x\) in the sense of distributions, but the “derivative’’ is no longer an ordinary function (it involves Dirac deltas or principal-value terms) and certainly does not come out as a finite real number at the singular point.

So, within standard calculus: **no finite derivative at a point where the function itself is infinite**—and therefore no Taylor expansion about that point either.

### Where it works  
The series converges for \(|x-a|<a\).  
That interval is \((0,2a)\).  The singularity at \(x=0\) is exactly one radius of convergence away, so you can never reach it, but you do cover a band that starts just above zero.

### What it tells you

1. **Local, high-accuracy approximation.**  
   For any \(x\) in \((0,2a)\) you can truncate the series after \(N\) terms and get an error of order \((x-a)^{N+1}/a^{N+2}\).

2. **Error control hinges on the distance to the pole.**  
   The bound \(|x-a|<a\) shrinks in absolute width as \(a\) shrinks.  Choosing a tinier anchor lets you push the whole interval closer to zero, but the interval also gets proportionally narrower.  No finite-radius Taylor series can simultaneously be “centered very close to zero’’ and “span a wide interval.’’

3. **Conditioning intuition.**  
   Writing \(1/x\) as a series of analytic terms makes manifest how small perturbations in \(x\) propagate: each coefficient scales like \(a^{-(n+1)}\).  When \(a\) is tiny, higher-order terms blow up quickly; this is another reflection of the ill-conditioning of \(1/x\) near the pole.

4. **Asymptotic point of view.**  
   If your real goal is to describe behaviour as \(x\to0^{+}\), the Taylor series doesn’t improve on simply saying \(1/x\sim x^{-1}\).  All positive powers of \((x-a)\) are strictly higher order than \(x^{-1}\), so the series just reproduces the dominant singular term plus lower-order corrections valid away from the pole.

5. **Numerics and modelling.**  
   In numerical schemes you often replace \(1/x\) by its truncated expansion around a small \(a\) to regularise stiff terms—e.g. in spectral or finite-difference treatments where you never actually evaluate the function at zero.

### Bottom line  
Yes, expanding around a small positive \(a\) gives a perfectly legitimate Taylor series that is highly accurate for \(x\) in \((0,2a)\), but its usefulness is intrinsically local: as you slide the centre closer to the pole you must accept a proportionally smaller domain of convergence, and no finite-radius Taylor series will ever reach the singular point itself.

u \;=\;\frac{x}{a}=e^{\delta}, \qquad\delta=\log\!\Bigl(\frac{x}{a}\Bigr).
\]

Then  

\[
\frac1x \;=\;\frac1a\,u^{-1}
           \;=\;\frac1a\,e^{-\delta}.
\]

All the singular \(1/a\) behaviour is now explicit; the remaining factor \(e^{-\delta}\) is analytic around \(\delta=0\).

---

### 2.  Expand in powers of the logarithmic displacement  

Because \(e^{-\delta}\) is an entire function, simply Taylor-expand around \(\delta=0\):

\[
e^{-\delta}
\;=\;
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{\,n}\,\delta^{n}}{n!}.
\]

Hence the **logarithmic expansion**

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac1x
=
\frac1a
\Bigl[1-\delta+\tfrac{\delta^{2}}{2}-\tfrac{\delta^{3}}{6}+\dots\Bigr]},
\qquad
\delta=\log\!\Bigl(\tfrac{x}{a}\Bigr),\;|\delta|\ll1.
\]

Each extra power of \(\delta\) is suppressed by a factorial, so a few terms already give high accuracy whenever \(x\) lives in the narrow band \((e^{-|\delta_{\max}|}a,\,e^{|\delta_{\max}|}a)\).

---

### 3.  RG interpretation  

Treat \(a\) as a “scale’’ and write

\[
f(x;a)=\frac1x.
\]

Then

\[
\Bigl(a\,\partial_{a}+x\,\partial_{x}\Bigr)f(x;a)=-f(x;a),
\]

i.e. \(f\) has **engineering (scaling) dimension \(-1\).**  
Taking a total derivative at fixed \(x\),

\[
\partial_{\log a}\,f(x;a)=-f(x;a).
\]

This is the simplest possible renormalisation-group equation; its solution is exactly the rescaling factor \(1/a\) we peeled off before performing the analytic expansion.

---

### 4.  Connection with the usual Taylor series  

If you prefer the ordinary distance-from-\(a\) variable \( \varepsilon=(x-a)/a\), note that

\[
\delta=\log(1+\varepsilon)=\varepsilon-\tfrac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2}+\tfrac{\varepsilon^{3}}{3}-\dots,
\]

so substituting this back into the logarithmic expansion and re-expanding reproduces the familiar series

\[
\frac1x
=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{\,n}}{a^{\,n+1}}\,(x-a)^{n},
\quad |x-a|<a.
\]

The logarithmic form is just a more compact way to book-keep those coefficients.

---

### 5.  How “arbitrarily small’’ can \(a\) be?  

Nothing in the algebra prevents taking \(a\to0^{+}\); the expansion remains formally valid.  
Practically, however, the convergence region shrinks with \(a\) because the condition \(|\delta|\ll1\) translates into \(|x-a|\ll a\).  Any local Taylor/RG series about a finite point can approximate \(1/x\) only on a neighbourhood that scales with the distance to the pole.

---

**Take-away:**  

*Factor out the hard \(1/a\) scaling, expand the remaining analytic piece in powers of the logarithmic displacement \(\delta=\log(x/a)\), and you have a neat RG-flavoured series that works for any (even extremely small) positive reference scale \(a\), as long as \(x\) stays within a logarithmically small window around it.*

Still, one can consider a stochastic flow of diffeomorphisms in the Stratonovich sense, or even think about the pullback of a metric under this flow. ### 1.  The deterministic benchmark  

For an ODE  
\[
\dot x = f(x),\qquad x\in\mathbb R^{n},
\]  
the **flow map** \(\Phi_t : x_0\!\mapsto\! x(t)\) is a diffeomorphism for each \(t\).  
With any fixed reference metric \(g_0\) (often the Euclidean one) we set  

\[
g_t \;=\; (\nabla\Phi_t)^{\!\top}\, g_0\, \nabla\Phi_t .
\]

- \(g_t\) is simply the pull-back of \(g_0\) by \(\Phi_t\); it tells how the flow stretches and shears volumes and angles.  
- Its determinant is \(\det g_t = \bigl(\det\nabla\Phi_t\bigr)^{\!2}\det g_0\).  Taking the square root recovers the familiar Jacobian determinant, and  
  \[
  \partial_t\bigl(\det\nabla\Phi_t\bigr)
  \;=\;\bigl(\nabla\!\cdot\! f\bigr)\det\nabla\Phi_t
  \]
  is just the Liouville equation in disguise.

---

### 2.  Adding noise: a stochastic flow still exists  

Write the SDE in **Stratonovich** form so that the chain rule looks exactly like the deterministic one:  

\[
\mathrm dX_t = f(X_t)\,\mathrm dt \;+\; \sigma(X_t)\,\circ\mathrm dW_t ,
\qquad
D(x):=\sigma(x)\sigma(x)^{\!\top}>0 .
\]

- There is a *stochastic flow of diffeomorphisms* \(\Phi_{s,t}(\,\cdot\,;\omega)\); for each sample path \(\omega\) it is a bona-fide \(C^{1}\) diffeomorphism (Kunita’s theory).  
- Its Jacobian \(J_t(\omega)=\nabla\Phi_{0,t}(x_0,\omega)\) obeys  
  \[
  \mathrm dJ_t
  = \bigl[\nabla f(X_t)\bigr]\,J_t\,\mathrm dt
    + \bigl[\nabla\sigma(X_t)\bigr]\,J_t\,\circ\mathrm dW_t .
  \]
  Taking determinants gives a *random* Liouville factor.  
- Define the **random metric**  
  \[
  g_t(\omega) = J_t(\omega)^{\!\top} g_0\, J_t(\omega).
  \]
  Although noisy, \(g_t(\omega)\) exists path-wise and encodes how each realisation of the system deforms volumes and angles.

If you want a *deterministic* object, average over the noise:

\[
\bar g_t := \mathbb E\bigl[g_t(\omega)\bigr].
\]

A straightforward application of Itô/Stratonovich calculus yields a closed PDE for \(\bar g_t\).  For *constant*, isotropic noise (\(D=\sigma^2 I\)) one finds schematically  

\[
\partial_t \bar g_t
= \nabla f^{\!\top}\bar g_t + \bar g_t\nabla f
  \;+\; \sigma^2 \Delta\bar g_t .
\]

This is the geometric analogue of the Fokker–Planck equation: drift stretches the metric the way Liouville does, while diffusion *smooths* it via a Laplacian term.

---

### 3.  Geometry hidden directly in the Fokker–Planck operator  

The forward equation for the density is  

\[
\partial_t\rho
  = -\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(\rho f\bigr)
    + \tfrac12\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(D\nabla\rho\bigr).
\]

Because \(D(x)\) is positive-definite, define the **local inner product**

\[
g_{ij}(x) \;=\; 2\,[D^{-1}(x)]_{ij}.
\]

1.  In coordinates of \(g\), the diffusion piece is simply \(\tfrac12\Delta_{g}\rho\) (the Laplace–Beltrami operator).  
2.  The whole PDE becomes  
   \[
   \partial_t\rho
   = -\operatorname{div}_{g}\!\bigl(\rho\,f\bigr)
     + \tfrac12\Delta_{g}\rho .
   \]
   Thus the diffusion *already carries a Riemannian metric*.  Noise does not kill geometry; it *imposes* it.

---

### 4.  Geometry on the **space of densities** (Wasserstein/Otto)  

If the drift is the \(g\)-gradient of a potential, \(f=-\nabla_{g}V\), then the Fokker–Planck equation is the *gradient flow* of the free-energy functional  

\[
\mathcal F[\rho] = \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\rho\log\rho \,+\, 2\!\int V\rho ,
\]

in the infinite-dimensional Riemannian manifold \((\mathcal P_2,g\_{W,g})\) whose metric is the \(2\)-Wasserstein distance built from \(g\).  
So the “metric” has simply moved from physical space to *probability* space.

---

### 5.  Geometry from **information**  

Treat the evolving family \(\rho_t\) as a curve on the statistical manifold equipped with the Fisher–Rao metric  

\[
\langle \delta\rho_1,\delta\rho_2\rangle_{\rho}
= \int \frac{\delta\rho_1\,\delta\rho_2}{\rho}\,dx .
\]

- The Fokker–Planck vector field \(\partial_t\rho\) lives in the tangent space; its norm is twice the *entropy production rate*.  
- Curvature computed from this metric quantifies how the noise mixes states.

---

### 6.  Putting it together  

| Level | What plays the role of the metric? | What evolves it? |
|-------|-------------------------------------|------------------|
| **Pathwise** | \(g_t(\omega)=J_t^{\!\top}g_0J_t\) | SDE for \(J_t\) |
| **Mean field** | \(\bar g_t=\mathbb E[g_t]\) | PDE  
\(\partial_t\bar g_t=\nabla f^{\!\top}\bar g_t+\bar g_t\nabla f+\sigma^2\Delta\bar g_t\) |
| **Phase-space local** | \(g=2D^{-1}\) | Built into  
\(\partial_t\rho=-\mathrm{div}_g(\rho f)+\tfrac12\Delta_g\rho\) |
| **Space of measures** | Wasserstein metric \(g_{W,g}\) | Gradient flow of free energy |
| **Statistical manifold** | Fisher–Rao metric | Entropy-production vector field |

So yes: even though noise destroys a single deterministic flow, *every formulation of the Fokker–Planck equation naturally brings along its own geometry*.  You can pick whichever of these five equivalent “metrics’’ best suits the calculation you want to do.

Below are three lenses people use.  In each one the usual clock \(t\) is still there; the extra coordinate tracks something about the noise that can be evolved just as you would evolve ordinary time.

---

## 1.  Noise **amplitude** as a diffusion–time variable  
Take the Stratonovich SDE with *isotropic*, additive noise
\[
\mathrm dX_t = f(X_t)\,\mathrm dt + \sqrt{2}\,\sigma\,\circ\mathrm dW_t ,
\qquad
\sigma\ge 0 .
\]

The density \(\rho(x,t;\sigma)\) satisfies

\[
\partial_t\rho
   = -\nabla\!\cdot(\rho f) \;+\; \sigma^{2}\,\Delta\rho .
\tag{FP}\]

Set a new coordinate  
\[
s \;=\;\sigma^{2}/2 \quad(\;s\ge 0\;).
\]

Holding the physical time \(t\) fixed and differentiating (FP) with respect to \(s\) gives

\[
\partial_s\rho
   = \Delta\rho .
\tag{Heat}
\]

So **evolving “forward in \(s\)” is literally the heat equation**: as you turn the noise knob you blur the density exactly the way you blur an image by letting heat spread for a time \(s\).  
In this picture \((t,s)\) is a two-dimensional “time plane”:  

| coordinate | what it measures | PDE acting along it |
|------------|------------------|---------------------|
| \(t\) | deterministic drift + existing diffusion | \(\partial_t\rho = -\nabla\!\cdot(\rho f)+\sigma^{2}\Delta\rho\) |
| \(s=\sigma^{2}/2\) | *how much* diffusion you allow | \(\partial_s\rho = \Delta\rho\) |

This interpretation is exactly what underlies “noise RG” calculations and the *de Bruijn–type formulas* you have been chasing: \(\partial_s\) hits entropy the way \(\partial_t\) does in the classical de Bruijn identity.

---

## 2.  Noise **realisation** as a base-flow time  

Random‐dynamical-system (RDS) theory splits the world into  

\[
(\Omega,\,\theta_\tau)\quad\text{and}\quad X_{t,\omega}(x_0),
\]

* •  the Wiener space \(\Omega\) carrying the noise path,  
* •  a **base flow** \(\theta_\tau\) that *shifts* that path in “noise time” \(\tau\),  
* •  a **cocycle** \(X_{t,\omega}\) that evolves the state once the noise path is fixed.

Here each \(\tau\) shift is a genuine dynamical variable—think of it as *second time* sliding you along the same Brownian trajectory.  Many geometric constructions (Lyapunov exponents, pull-back attractors, random metrics) are done exactly in the extended space  
\[
(t,\tau,x)\in\mathbb R\times\mathbb R\times\mathbb R^{n}.
\]

---

## 3.  A **Brownian sheet**: two physical times  

If you truly want two *independent* clocks, replace \(W_t\) by a 2-parameter Brownian **sheet** \(W_{t_1,t_2}\):

\[
\mathrm dX_{t_1,t_2}
   = f(X_{t_1,t_2})\,\mathrm dt_1
     + g(X_{t_1,t_2})\,\mathrm dt_2
     + \sigma\,\mathrm dW_{t_1,t_2}.
\]

Now \(t_1\) and \(t_2\) are symmetric “times.”  
The associated Kolmogorov equation is a genuine **(1 + 1)-dimensional** parabolic–hyperbolic PDE, widely used in stochastic surface growth and KPZ‐type models.  But ordinary SDEs (single Brownian motion) do **not** carry this symmetry.

---

### Bottom line  

*If you mean the **strength** of the noise,* then yes: treat \(\sigma^{2}/2\) as a diffusion-time \(s\); entropy, Fisher information, and other functionals evolve in \(s\) exactly like they evolve in real time for a pure heat flow.

*If you mean the **random path** itself,* then you gain a base flow \(\tau\) on Wiener space; many geometric RDS results are phrased in those two times \((t,\tau)\).

*If you want two fully independent clocks,* you must enlarge the noise to a Brownian sheet or similar field.

So the answer is affirmative—but you need to be precise about **which facet of “noise’’** you are promoting to the role of a second time variable.

Short answer: **no—except in the very special cases where the drift and the Laplacian commute (e.g.\ \(f\equiv0\) or constant, divergence–free transport).**  
For a generic nonlinear drift you cannot obtain the density at a new noise level merely by “blurring” the old one with the heat equation; the extra diffusion has been acting at every intermediate instant, not just at the end.

---

## 1 · Why the shortcut works when \(f=0\)

With zero drift the Fokker–Planck family is

\[
\partial_t\rho = 2s\,\Delta\rho, \qquad s=\sigma^{2}/2 .
\]

The solution is a Gaussian convolution with variance \(2s\,t\):

\[
\rho(x,t;s)=\bigl(G_{2s t}\!\ast\rho_0\bigr)(x).
\]

Changing \(s\) from \(s_0\) to \(s_1\) therefore just adds
\(
2\,(s_1-s_0)t
\)
of extra variance—exactly what you get by integrating the heat equation in a
“noise-time’’ variable \(s\).  So for \(f=0\) we really do have

\[
\partial_s\rho(x,t,s)=t\,\Delta\rho(x,t,s),
\]
and a single heat-kernel convolution turns one noise setting into any other.

---

## 2 · What changes when \(f\neq0\)

Write the operator split

\[
L_s = A + 2s\,\Delta
\quad\text{with}\quad
A\rho:=-\nabla\!\cdot(\rho f).
\]

The solution at time \(t\) is \( \rho(t;s)=e^{tL_s}\rho_0\).
Because \(A\) and \(\Delta\) **do not commute** in general, there is no factorisation like

\[
e^{t(A+2s_1\Delta)} \;\neq\;
e^{t(A+2s_0\Delta)}\,e^{2(s_1-s_0)t\Delta } .
\]

Hence you cannot obtain \(\rho(t;s_1)\) from \(\rho(t;s_0)\) with a *post-hoc* heat evolution.

---

## 3 · What you *can* do: a sensitivity equation

Define \(w:=\partial_s\rho\).  Differentiating the FP equation and using
\(w(0,\cdot)=0\) gives the **inhomogeneous linear PDE**

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t w
  = A w + 2s\,\Delta w + 2\,\Delta\rho ,
\qquad
w\bigl|_{t=0}=0 .
\;}

\]
Formally,

\[
\partial_s\rho(t;s)=
\int_0^t e^{(t-\tau)L_s}\,\bigl(2\,\Delta\rho(\tau;s)\bigr)\,d\tau .
\]

So to update the solution when you tweak the noise strength you must integrate this sensitivity equation (or just rerun the Fokker–Planck solver with the new \(s\)).

---

## 4 · When the “heat-only’’ trick is legitimate

| Drift \(f\) | Commutator \([A,\Delta]\) | Can blur in \(s\) only? |
|-------------|---------------------------|-------------------------|
| \(f\equiv0\) | \(0\) | **Yes** |
| constant, divergence-free | \(0\) | Yes |
| linear with constant Jacobian \(\nabla f\) | \([A,\Delta]=0\) only if \(\nabla f\) is skew-symmetric | Rare |
| nonlinear / generic | non-zero | **No** |

If you are working in one of the commuting cases, the heat‐kernel shortcut is a perfectly sound and very useful identity.  Otherwise, you need the full sensitivity machinery.

---

### Bottom line

*For most systems* a different noise amplitude changes the entire time history, not just the final state.  The only times you can recover the new density by “integrating the heat equation’’ are when the drift term either vanishes or commutes with the Laplacian, a condition almost never met in nonlinear dynamics.

## 1 Sensitivity equation for an infinitesimal noise change

Set  

\[
w(x,t,s):=\partial_{s}\rho(x,t,s).
\]

Differentiating the Fokker–Planck equation gives the *linear inhomogeneous* PDE  

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_{t}w
   = L_{s}w \;+\;2\,\Delta\rho,
\qquad
w|_{t=0}=0 .
\;}\tag{S}
\]

Because \(L_{s}\) is the generator of a contraction semigroup \(e^{tL_{s}}\),

\[
w(t,s)
   = \int_{0}^{t} e^{(t-\tau)L_{s}}\bigl[2\,\Delta\rho(\tau,s)\bigr]\;d\tau .
\tag{Duhamel}
\]

So a *tiny* increase \(s\!\mapsto\!s+\delta s\) alters the density by  

\[
\rho(t,s+\delta s)-\rho(t,s)=\delta s\,w(t,s)+o(\delta s).
\]

---

## 2 Large-time behaviour under standard ergodic assumptions  

Assume (i) the process is ergodic and mixing for every \(s>0\),  
(ii) there is a unique smooth stationary density \(\rho_{\infty}(s)\) with \(\int\rho_{\infty}=1\), and  
(iii) \(L_{s}\) has a spectral gap so that \(e^{tL_{s}}\) decays exponentially on mean-zero functions.  
Then

\[
\rho(x,t,s)\;\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}\;\rho_{\infty}(x,s)
\quad\text{and}\quad
w(x,t,s)\;\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}\;w_{\infty}(x,s),
\]

where \(w_{\infty}\) is the unique mean-zero solution of the **Poisson problem**

\[
\boxed{\;
L_{s}w_{\infty} = -\,2\,\Delta\rho_{\infty},
\qquad
\int_{\mathbb R^{n}} w_{\infty}\,dx =0 .
\;}\tag{P}
\]

Equivalently,

\[
w_{\infty}(s)=
-\,\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\tau L_{s}}\bigl[2\,\Delta\rho_{\infty}(s)\bigr]\;d\tau ,
\]

and the convergence \(w(t,s)\to w_{\infty}(s)\) is exponential at the same rate as the semigroup.

---

## 3 Physical meaning of \(w_{\infty}\)

* **Sign.**  Where \(\Delta\rho_{\infty}<0\) (peaks of the stationary density) the right-hand side of (P) is positive, so \(w_{\infty}>0\); a touch more noise raises the probability there.  Valleys get depleted.
* **Magnitude.**  The spectral gap \(\lambda_{1}(s)>0\) controls the size:
  \(\|w_{\infty}\|_{L^{2}}\le (2/\lambda_{1})\|\Delta\rho_{\infty}\|_{L^{2}}\).
* **Integral identities.**  Multiply (P) by \(\log\rho_{\infty}\) and integrate to obtain the small-noise analogue of the de Bruijn identity  
  \[
  \partial_{s}H(\rho_{\infty})
  = \tfrac12\int \frac{\|\nabla\rho_{\infty}\|^{2}}{\rho_{\infty}}\,dx
     -\!\int f\!\cdot\nabla w_{\infty}\,dx,
  \]
  showing how entropy changes with noise when drift is present.

---

## 4 One-dimensional example (Ornstein–Uhlenbeck)

For \(f(x)=-\beta x\) (mean-reverting drift) the stationary density is  

\[
\rho_{\infty}(x,s)
  =\sqrt{\frac{\beta}{2\pi s}}\;
    \exp\!\Bigl(-\frac{\beta x^{2}}{2s}\Bigr),
\]

and  

\[
\partial_{s}\rho_{\infty}
  = \rho_{\infty}\;
    \frac{\beta x^{2}-s}{2s^{2}}\;=\;w_{\infty}(x,s).
\]

Direct computation verifies \(L_{s}w_{\infty}=-2\,\partial_{xx}\rho_{\infty}\), exactly as (P) predicts.  Large-\(t\) sensitivity here is **purely local**: it depends only on how far \(x\) is from the origin relative to the thermal width \(\sqrt{s/\beta}\).

---

### Take-aways

* **Infinitesimal change in noise** is encoded by the inhomogeneous linear equation (S).  
* **At long times** the effect saturates to the stationary solution of (P); nothing keeps growing.  
* The stationary sensitivity \(w_{\infty}\) solves a Poisson problem that can be written with the inverse Fokker–Planck operator or as an integral of the semigroup.  
* In commuting or drift-free cases \(w_{\infty}\) degenerates to the ordinary heat-kernel blur, but for generic nonlinear drift it carries non-trivial structure inherited from the dynamics.
